Soderstrom and Ellis (1987) propose including \i{}Ampelocalamus\i0{} Chen, Wen and Shang, \i{}Chimonocalamus\i0{} Hsueh and Yi, \i{}Drepanostachyum\i0{} Keng f. and \i{}Sinarundinaria\i0{} Nakai, and speak elsewhere (1988) of fargesioid \i{}Arundinaria\i0{} species. Clayton and Renvoize include the first three in \i{}Sinarundinaria\i0{}, and include \i{}Fargesia\i0{} in \i{}Thamnocalamus\i0{}. To further complicate matters, \i{}Sinarundinaria\i0{} is sometimes presented as a synonym of \i{}Phyllostachys\i0{} Sieb. and Zucc.>
<description scarcely adequate, e.g. lacking information on spikelet orientation>

<nomenclatural and taxonomic confusion involves this genus and \i{}Rhomboelytrum\i0{}. This morphological description includes \i{}R. berteroanum\i0{} = \i{}G. jaffuelii\i0{} or \i{}G. filiformis\i0{}>
<lacking reliable data on ligule form, spikelet orientation, lemma form, number of stigmas, etc>

<This is a currently inadequate description of a \i{}Stipa\i0{} segregate, consisting of \i{}S. comata\i0{}, \i{}S. curtiseta\i0{}, \i{}S. neomexicana\i0{} and \i{}S. spartea\i0{}. See further comment under \i{}Stipa\i0{} sensu lato.>
<referred to \i{}Drake-Brockmania\i0{} by Phillips (1974), but in view of the morphological differences, anatomical data are badly needed for \i{}H. haareri\i0{} and \i{}B. fragilis\i0{}>

<worthy of detailed anatomical study based on better material than that seen. The presence of abundant microhairs on the submerged, astomatal abaxial blade surface is odd, and many of the vascular bundles are associated with an abaxial sclerenchyma group incorporating an extraordinarily large, lignified element>

<An as yet incomplete description of a \i{}Stipa\i0{} segregate, previously \i{}Stipa\i0{} subg. \i{}Jarava\i0{}). \i{}Jarava\i0{} includes \i{}S. ambigua\i0{}, \i{}Stipa breviseta\i0{}, \i{}Stipa eriostachya\i0{}, \i{}S. gynerioides\i0{}, \i{}S. ichu\i0{} (= \i{}Achnatherum ichu\i0{}), \i{}S. plumosa\i0{} (= \i{}Stipa papposa\i0{}, \i{}Achnatherum papposa\i0{}), \i{}S. pseudoichu\i0{}, \i{}S. pugionata\i0{}, \i{}S. pungens\i0{}, \i{}S. subaristata\i0{}. The present morphological description is based mainly on \i{}J. plumosa\i0{} (= \i{}Stipa papposa\i0{} nom. illeg., \i{}Achnatherum papposum\i0{})>

<based on the very poor original generic description and illustrations of \i{}K. gobicola\i0{}, with no information on spikelet orientation, lodicules, fruit form, etc. (Yen and Yang 1990), supplemented by the brief illustrated description of \i{}K. mutica\i0{} by Yang \i{}et al.\i0{} (1995)>

<the taxonomic situation around \i{}Koeleria\i0{} and \i{}Trisetum\i0{} (involving \i{}Trisetaria\i0{}, \i{}Graphephorum\i0{}, \i{}Rostraria\i0{}, \i{}Lophochloa\i0{} and \i{}Peyritschia\i0{}) is hopelessly unsatisfactory, and demands either a world monograph of the approximately 150 species involved, or critical assessment via extensive worldwide sampling and an adequate character list. This sensu lato version of \i{}Koeleria\i0{} reflects the impossibility of preparing adequate descriptions for segregate genera, and is poorly separable from that of \i{}Trisetum\i0{}>

<description restricted to \i{}L. hildebrandtii\i0{} (Hack.) Stapf. Stapfs (1926) dismissal of the hairy ovary apex is untenable, and Bossers association of two \i{}Miscanthidium\i0{} species with \i{}L. hildebrandtii\i0{} is unconvincing. The material seen (Hildebrandt 3755) has most of the pedicellate spikelets male, except near the baranch tips. Glabrous lodicules (seen in some of the florets examined, cf. Bosser 1968) may reflect easily dislodged hairs (observed in other florets)>
<description hopelessly inadequate for reliable classificatory assignment>
<Tendencies previously used to separate \i{}Diplachne\i0{} as a genus or Section of \i{}Leptochloa\i0{} are indicated>
<note that there are serious taxonomic problems involving \i{}Leptochloa\i0{}, \i{}Trichoneura\i0{}, \i{}Diplachne\i0{}, etc.>
<possible intergeneric hybrids, involving \i{}Lepturus\i0{} as one parent>
<morphological description revised by E.A. Kellogg, November 1988>

<An isolated genus of uncertain taxonomic affinities, despite good descriptive data. Primitive numerical taxonomic analyses of Metcalfes leaf blade anatomical descriptions conducted in 1963 (Watson, unpublished) presented \i{}Lygeum\i0{} with \i{}Nardus\i0{} as an outlying group, and this has been a consistent feature of most analyses performed subsequently in course of developing this data set. They seem closest to Stipeae, but are prime candidates for comparative DNA studies.>
<one of several danthonioid genera still somewhat arbitrarily referred here to Arundinoideae rather than Chloridoideae; see Watson et al. (1985)>

<a taxonomic puzzle - cf. \i{}Danthoniastrum\i0{}? The embryo structure as described by Tateoka (1964) is emphatically \i{}not\i0{} pooid, the lodicules are stipoid, and the leaf anatomical evidence (see above) is ambiguous. Reliable taxonomic assignment requires that adaxial leaf epidermis, glumes, lemmas and lodicules be examined for microhairs, and that cytological information be obtained>
<see comment under \i{}Anadelphia\i0{} regarding unsatisfactory taxonomy involving \i{}Monium\i0{}, \i{}Anadelphia\i0{} and \i{}Pobeguinea\i0{}>

<cf. \i{}Indosasa\i0{}, \i{}Schizostachyum\i0{}. The ovary apex (not mentioned in the original, unsatisfactory Latin descriptions) is assumed to be unappendaged. The only other difference from \i{}Schizostachyum\i0{} is the glabrous lodicules>

<An isolated genus of uncertain taxonomic affinities, despite excellent descriptive data. Primitive numerical taxonomic analyses of Metcalfes leaf blade anatomical descriptions conducted in 1963 (Watson, unpublished) presented \i{}Nardus\i0{} with \i{}Lygeum\i0{} as an outlying group, and this has been a consistent feature of most analyses performed subsequently in course of developing this data set. They seem closest to Stipeae, but are prime candidates for comparative DNA studies.>
<This description is an attempt to portray \i{}Nassella\i0{} sensu lato (cf. Barkworth 1990), which takes in numerous South American species formerly assigned to \i{}Stipa\i0{}.>

<very distinct from typical \i{}Eragrostis\i0{}, judging from Nicoras thorough description; but the distinction is blurred by (e.g.) \i{}E. hypnoides\i0{} (Lam.) B.S.P. and especially by \i{}E. contrerasii\i0{} Pohl, which is also dioecious with creeping habit>

<probably another odd \i{}Digitaria\i0{} relative, as assigned by Filgueiras \i{}et al.\i0{}, although a preliminary INTKEY exploration based on this description suggests there is as much in common with \i{}Paspalum\i0{} and even with some Andropogoneae (Rottboelliinae, e.g. \i{}Phacelurus\i0{})>

<the North American species usually known as \i{}Oryzopsis micrantha\i0{} and \i{}O. racemosa\i0{} are referred here to the otherwise Old World genus \i{}Piptatherum\i0{}, and \i{}O. hymenoides\i0{} to \i{}Achnatherum\i0{}, cf. Barkworth 1993. This at least permits \i{}Oryzopsis\i0{} sensu stricto to be distinguished from \i{}Piptatherum\i0{} on morphological grounds, but negates the former geographical distinction. While \i{}Oryzopsis\i0{} sensu lato (i.e. including \i{}Piptatherum\i0{}) is clearly unsatisfactory, the present solution is probably transient>

<see Clayton and Renvoize (1986) and Soderstrom and Ellis (1987) for very different generic interpretations of the species in this circle of affinity. There are no available generic descriptions adequate for the present purpose>
<The morphological description incorporates corrections forwarded by J.F. Veldkamp (1997), who draws attention to peculiarities of the Malesian species, \i{}O. grandiflora\i0{}.>

<generic limits among the relatives of \i{}Panicum\i0{} (\i{}Ancistrachne\i0{}, \i{}Brachiaria\i0{}, \i{}Dichanthelium\i0{}, \i{}Digitaria\i0{}, \i{}Eriochloa\i0{}, \i{}Homolepis\i0{}, \i{}Hylebates\i0{}, \i{}Hymenachne\i0{}, \i{}Ichnanthus\i0{}, \i{}Paspalidium\i0{}, \i{}Sacciolepis\i0{}, \i{}Setaria\i0{}, \i{}Tricholaena\i0{}, \i{}Urochloa\i0{}, \i{}Whiteochloa\i0{} etc., and many small segregates) need critical revision in terms of comparative data recorded at world level. Consequent re-alignments of species might reduce the variability here attributed to \i{}Panicum\i0{}. See W. V. Brown (1977) for discussion, and Zuloaga (1987) for a detailed treatment of the \i{}New World\i0{} species. Occasional species with a rachilla prolongation or a second sterile floret, and small suites of species with laterally compressed spikelets, secund one-sided inflorescence branches, stipitate upper florets, linear hila, etc., pose major hazards for printed generic keys; and for use in in that context, the description of \i{}Panicum\i0{} as encoded here will generally require editing at regional level. The agriculturally important species \i{}P. maximum\i0{} well illustrates the situation. It may belong with species currently referred to \i{}Urochloa\i0{} and/or \i{}Brachiaria\i0{} (PCK, rugose upper lemma, etc.), but changes of this kind cannot be effectively implemented until the generic circumscriptions have been clarified (cf. Webster 1987, Zuloaga 1987)>
<somewhat marginally separable from \i{}Setaria\i0{}: even the difference in arrangement of primary inflorescence branches seems to be not quite absolute>
<morphological description scarcely adequate - e.g. spikelet orientation unknown>
<the spikelet morphology is evidently difficult, and this description reflects very tentative interpretation of depauperate and inadequate (type) material>

<Including the North American species usually known as \i{}Oryzopsis micranthum\i0{} and \i{}O. racemosa\i0{} in \i{}Piptatherum\i0{} (cf. Barkworth 1993) permits this genus to be distinguished morphologically from \i{}Oryzopsis\i0{} sensu stricto, while disavowing Freitags geographical distinction.>
<Taxonomic relationships impossible to determine reliably with neither leaf anatomical nor photosynthetic pathway data.>

<only male plants have yet been formally described inder this genus. It is now established that \i{}Pennisetum arnhemicum\i0{} F. Muell. is the male component (Lazarides and Macfarlane, \i{}pers. comm.\i0{}), but full details and the revised generic circumscription are not yet formally published>
<A \i{}Stipa\i0{} segregate containing \i{}S. kingii\i0{}, \i{}S. mongholica\i0{}, etc., unsatisfactorily delimited from \i{}Achnatherum\i0{}. See further comments under \i{}Stipa\i0{} sensu lato.>

<The status of the poorly known \i{}R. prainii\i0{} (Gamble) Keng (= \i{}Arundinaria prainii\i0{}, \i{}Microcalamus prainii\i0{}, \i{}Neomicrocalamus\i0{} Keng f.) is uncertain: see Dransfield (1992)>
<rows of crypts containing crystalline material (NaCl?) occur within the grooves if the leaf blade>

<Clayton and Renvoize (1986) and Soderstrom and Ellis (1987) present very different generic interpretations of the species associated with \i{}Sinarundinaria\i0{}, \i{}Otatea\i0{}, \i{}Yushania\i0{}, \i{}Fargesia\i0{} and \i{}Thamnocalamus\i0{} (q.v.), without providing generic descriptions adequate for the present purpose, and the data compiled here are inevitably very unsatisfactory>
<fairly arbitrarily but mostly readily separable from \i{}Eragrostis\i0{}; see also \i{}Thellungia\i0{}>

<This sensu lato description is retained, pending preparation of adequately detailed, comparative descriptions for the segregate genera \i{}Achnatherum\i0{}, \i{}Austrostipa\i0{}, \i{}Hesperostipa\i0{} \i{}Ptilagrostis\i0{} and \i{}Stipa\i0{} sensu stricto (see Barkworth and Everett 1987, Barkworth 1993, Jacobs and Everett 1996) and worldwide assignments of species to them. Freitags (1985) preference for sensu lato treatment pending a much needed worldwide monograph has much merit.>

<This is an unsatisfactory attempt to account for the proposed sensu stricto treatment of \i{}Stipa\i0{}. Supposedly characteristic rectangular abaxial leaf blade epidermal silica bodies (Barkworth and Everett 1987) are refuted by Metcalfes detailed descriptions of two of the best known species. See further comment under \i{}Stipa\i0{} sensu lato.>

<\i{}Streptostachys\i0{} as carefully re-circumscribed by Morrone and Zuloaga (i.e. with \i{}S. aucuminata\i0{} referred to \i{}Urochloa\i0{}, and \i{}S. robusta\i0{} excluded) continues to present a wonderful blend of panicoid and bambusoid features, and is very unusual in including both C\sub{}3\nosupersub{} and C\sub{}4\nosupersub{} species>

<these very inadequate data have been encoded, with some tentative guesswork, from the original very poor description and illustration. The former (including Latin diagnosis) occupies only one page, but includes the statement Caryopsis not seen, separated by 8 lines from fruit ellipsoid, pallid. Ligule, spikelet orientation, female-fertile palea, lodicules, androecium (etc.) are neither dealt with in the text nor represented in the illustration>
<some cultivated specimens hint at hybridization with \i{}Fingerhuthia\i0{}>

<see Clayton and Renvoize (1986) and Soderstrom and Ellis (1987) for completely different generic interpretations of the species in this circle of affinity: there are no available generic descriptions adequate for the present purpose>
<bridging \i{}Sporobolus\i0{} and \i{}Eragrostis\i0{}, and incompletely separable from the latter in terms of the current descriptions>

<Linder and Davidse (1997) include the very aberrant \i{}T. pusillum\i0{} here on cladistic grounds; arguing that because its numerous characteristics are interpreted as \i{}unique autapomorphies\i0{}, recognition of the monotypic genus \i{}Urochlaena\i0{} renders \i{}Tribolium\i0{} paraphyletic. Such rather startling applications of cladistic theory are at odds with the practical requirement that taxonomic systems should facilitate making generalisations; and in view of the well known difficulties regarding extent of sampling and interpretations of morphological characters and character states, and taxonomic sampling limitations (notably, lack of information on extinct forms), corrobarative evidence from nucleic acid sequencing seems essential. In this instance, the latter may exist, but seemingly remains unpublished.>

<see description of \i{}Koeleria\i0{} for comments on the unsatisfactory taxonomic situation around \i{}Koeleria\i0{} and \i{}Trisetum\i0{} (involving \i{}Trisetaria\i0{}, \i{}Graphephorum\i0{}, \i{}Rostraria\i0{}, \i{}Lophochloa\i0{} and \i{}Peyritschia\i0{})>
<For justification of this sensu lato treatment of \i{}Urochloa\i0{}, see taxonomic comments under \i{}Brachiaria\i0{}.>

<see Clayton and Renvoize (1986) and Soderstrom and Ellis (1987) for very different generic interpretations of species in this circle of affinity: there are no available generic descriptions adequate for the present purpose>

<the descriptions of maize relatives require updating, to conform with modern taxonomic views (e.g. Doebley and Iltis 1980, Iltis 1987). The older and convenient but artificial treatment, separating the readily distinguishable \i{}Zea mays\i0{} subsp. \i{}mays\i0{} from the rest, is retained here pending acqisition of detailed comparative morphological data>

<adequacy of> anatomical data <for reliability of implicit states>

data: <very common in the temperate areas of South-eastern Australia, from the Downs in southern Queensland to the Eyre Peninsula and Tasmania. Over this area the genus typically dominates the grasslands in sunny habitats, and several species are important grazing grasses. Extends to W.A.>
<restricted to Northern N.S.W., Qld and N.T.>
<\i{}Jarava plumosa\i0{} occurs in a very restricted area of Adelaide as a weed, having escaped from a trial planting>
<restricted to the sandstones of south-eastern Australia.>
<restricted to the arid and semi-arid regions of central Australia>

characters.name: <additional comments re Australian genera:>
data: <a genus of c. 5 species native to the Old World tropics; 2 are native in Australia>
<A tropical genus of 4 species with 1 in the Philippines, 1 in New Caledonia and 2 endemic in Australia>
<An isolated genus, the affinities of which within the Pooideae are still obscure; possibly near the Stipeae>
<A genus of 3 species endemic in Australia>
<a pantropic genus of c. 55 species with most species in Asia. Of the 4 species native to Australia 2 are narrow endemics in SE Queensland, 1 tropical and 1 widespread in the tropics and subtropics>

<all species are palatable and valuable pasture grasses, with \i{}A. lappacea\i0{} also cultivated for fodder. \par{}The common name is in honour of Sir Thomas Mitchell who collected the first recorded specimens near Condobolin, N.S.W. in 1836. Mitchell grasses are restricted to the black, grey, brown and red cracking clay soils, and are usually a major element in grassland communities on these soils. They are well known for their drought resistance, persistence and fodder value. In many areas of Qld, there is a cyclic oscillation between Mitchell Grass dominance and Queensland Bluegrass (\i{}Dicantheum sericeum\i0{}) dominance, according to the particular sequence of wet or dry seasons. \par{}Although the species are readily distinguished, probable interspecific hybrids occur but are mostly sterile. Self-fertilizaton under experimental conditions has been reported for all four species, and evidence of cleistogamy seen in all species except \i{}A. squarrosa\i0{}>

<\i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{} is very close to \i{}Joycea\i0{}, \i{}Notodanthonia\i0{} \i{}Rytidosperma\i0{} and \i{}Karroochloa\i0{}, and over the past two decades there have been many suggestions as to the most appropriate taxonomy for this group. Here we follow a narrow generic approach, which leaves \i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{} defined on the presence of a large callus, and a lemma indumentum more or less as tufts.>
<A genus of c. 110 species native to the warmer areas of the Western Hemisphere. Some are important native forage species whereas others are weedy invaders of which 2 are introduced into Australia.>
<\i{}B. vulgaris\i0{} Schrad. ex J.C.Wendl. and \i{}B. balcooa\i0{} Roxb. occur in coastal areas of northern N.S.W. and in Qld, however it is doubtful if either is naturalized>
<a genus of 3 species native to Africa and the Mediterranean. One introduced species in Australia.>
<a widespread genus of 22 species in tropical and warm temperate regions. Ten species in Australia, 3 native and 7 introduced>
<\i{}Chionochloa\i0{} is only dubiously distinct from \i{}Cortaderia\i0{}, and \i{}C. archboldii\i0{} from Papua New Guinea is intermediate between these two genera.>

<native and introduced species both exhibit weedy behaviour, frequently establishing on disturbed ground, with \i{}C. virgata\i0{} and \i{}C. inflata\i0{} being the most aggressive. A number of species are useful forage grasses and soil binders, some with salt- and drought-tolerant properties. At least one Australian collection of \i{}C. ciliata\i0{} Sw. is known, from planted pasture E of the Great Dividing Range in central eastern Qld. The golden indurated lower lemma with strongly ciliate margins and keel, and the very short straight awns clearly distinguish it from native or naturalised species in Australia>
<A genus of three species all native to Australia>
<A genus of about 10 species in tropical Australia, Asia and Africa; 1 endemic in Australia>

<\i{}Cortaderia\i0{} is a rather heterogenous genus, and may not be monophyletic. In addition, the relationship to \i{}Chionochloa\i0{} is not clear, and \i{}C. archboldii\i0{} from Papua New Guinea is intermediate between the two genera. The species limits in the adventive species are difficult to determine, and the species-level taxonomy of the genus is still in an unsatisfactory state.>

<A genus of 12 species native to the Old World tropics, including 2 in the tropics of north Qld. \i{}C. deltoideum\i0{} (Hack.) A.Camus has been introduced into Australia but has not become established>

<This description represents the Northern hemisphere component of the old \i{}Danthonia\i0{} complex, plus the widespread \i{}Sieglingia decumbens\i0{}, in conformity with recent treatments of the complex. \i{}Danthonia\i0{} thus circumscribed seems is fairly homogenous, and is claimed to be probably monophyletic. However, as the above description shows, \i{}Sieglingia\i0{} (described separately in this data set) is known in more detail than the rest, and there remain several species needing further attention. In particular, the Himalayan species are inadequately known.>
<A large cosmopolitan genus of 220 species; 39 species in Australia, 32 native and 7 introduced>
<A genus of 30-40 species in warm regions; 17 species in Australia, 9 native and 8 introduced. This treatment follows the concepts of P.W.Michael & J.W.Vickery (1980)>
<This rather peculiar and poorly known genus is probably most closely related to the crinipoid Danthonieae, but the complex morphology has not been adequately studied>
<A genus of 5 species, 2 in tropical Africa are semi-aquatic while the 3 species endemic to Australia occur in rocky outcrops in woodlands>

<A genus of 30 species throughout the tropics and subtropics with 5 species native to Australia. Some species provide forage in native pastures. The genus is unique in that the first glume is reduced and modified to form a cup-like structure surrounding the base of the spikelet. This structure is fused towards the base to the rachilla, which is well-developed between the glumes>
<a close-knit group of species possessing a particular combination of characters, but otherwise barely separable from Chloris>
<A monotypic genus endemic in SE Qld>
<A genus with 29 species from the Seychelles, Indo-Malesia, southern China, Philippines, New Guinea, Fiji, Society and Cook Islands and Hawaii; 1 species in Australia>
<two were reported to be good pasture grasses by Ewart & Davies (1917)>
<A genus of 4 species from East Africa, southern India, Sri Lanka and Australia; 1 endemic species in Qld>
<A genus of 3 species endemic in northern and eastern Australia>
<An Australian endemic genus consisting of 2 distinct species>
<About 8 species native to the tropics of Asia, Australia and the Americas; 1 species native in Australia>
<A tropical genus with 1 species in the Old World and approximately 38 species native to America; 1 species native in Australia>
<About 60 species native to the tropics with many in Asia; 3 species in Australia, 2 native and 1 introduced>

<Closely related to \i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{} and \i{}Notodanthonia\i0{}, but differs by the scattered lemma indumentum, and the relatively long hilum on the seed. In addition, the plants are generally not palatable, and are found on gravelly soils.>
<the variablity of \i{}L. repens\i0{} leads to wide differences in the number of species accepted>

<A genus of 12 species, most native to tropical and southern Africa, Madagascar, tropical South America and the West Indies. One introduced species in Australia. The foliage is aromatic and covered with viscid hairs>

<A very peculiar, monotypic, Australian genus. The affinities are not at all clear, and the problem of the relationships of this genus are further compounded by the high ploidy level, suggesting hybridization (with what?) in the past.>
<related to \i{}Triodia\i0{} by virtue of its leaf and awn anatomy, but differing in the single bisexual floret per spikelet and in the long, single, terminal awn on the lemma>
<An isolated genus, possibly closest to the Stipeae>
<a genus of 6 species native to Australia>
<\i{}Notochloe\i0{} appears to be most closely related to \i{}Plinthanthesis\i0{}, both on leaf anatomy, and on molecular sequence data>
<\i{}Notodanthonia\i0{} is very close to \i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{}, from which it differs by the velvety indumentum on the lemma backs, and the row of long hairs directly below the lemma sinus>
<About 7 species native to the tropics and subtropics, with 4 species native to Australia>
<A tropical genus of 5 species with 1 in Africa, 3 in Asia and 2 native in Australia.>
<a variable genus of about 500 to 600 species; 35 species in Australia, 22 native and 13 introduced>
<A monotypic endemic genus occurring in the arid and semiarid regions of central Australia>
<An endemic genus of 2 species in northern and central Australia>
<A taxonomically difficult genus of about 27 species, 23 native in Australia>

<Approximately 250 species primarily found in the tropics and subtropics, concentrated in the New World where they are important in native grasslands. In Australia, 4 species are native and 12 are introduced. Numerous species have been introduced in experimental plots in Queensland and Western Australia. Many \i{}Paspalum\i0{} species are noxious weeds whereas others have proved to be excellent in improved pastures>
<An economically important genus of c. 70 species; 11 species in Australia, 1 is endemic and 10 are naturalised by the introduction of numerous species for agricultural purposes>

<The closest affinities of \i{}Pentaschistis\i0{} are with several other African genera, such as \i{}Pentameris\i0{}, \i{}Chaetobromus\i0{} and \i{}Prionanthium\i0{}. It shares with these genera a reduction to two florets per spikelet, and lemma setae that are inserted at the base of the lemma lobes, rather than at the apex of the lobes. The genus is regarded as core danthonioid.>

<in addition to the naturalized species, the first record of \i{}P. brachystachys\i0{} is reported from a cultivated specimen from S.A., \i{}P. lemmoni\i0{} is reported as occurring in NE Victoria, from specimens held at US, by Anderson (1961, although no collections are known in Australia), and \i{}P. daviesii\i0{} is a hybrid between \i{}P. minor\i0{} and \i{}P. aquatica\i0{} cultivated in Australia and introduced elsewhere (Africa and South America) as a forage grass>

<\i{} Phragmites \i0{} is a cosmopolitan genus of 3 species, the taxonomy of which is difficult, due to the extensive variation between the continents, as well as on a equatorial-polar gradient. The currently most widely accepted taxonomy recognises three species. \i{}P. australis \i0{} is largely a temperate, bihemipsherical species, while the tropical species are \i{}P. mauritianus \i0{} and \i{}P. karka\i0{}. There is extensive variation within each species. This applies particularly to \i{}P. australis\i0{}, while \i{}P. mauritianus \i0{}is a tropical African endemic, and \i{}P. karka \i0{} is found on all continents, and is also tropical. While the differences between \i{}P. karka \i0{} and \i{}P. australis \i0{} are not very clearcut, and many collections are difficult to assign to species. \i{}P. karka \i0{} and \i{}P. mauritianus\i0{}are even more difficult to separate. If they are the same species, it would be called \i{}P. mauritianus \i0{}, as this is the oldest name.>
<A small, distinctive genus, taxonomically isolated. Recent analyses suggest a relationship to \i{}Notochloe\i0{}>
<About 5 widespread species native to India and Japan to Australia, 3 species are native in Australia>
<Primarily an African genus of about 17 species with 1 species introduced into Australia>

<\i{}Rytidosperma\i0{}, as defined here, includes the upland species from Papua New Guinea to New Zealand, and the South American species. It is close to \i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{}, from which it can be separated by the shorter callus, and to \i{}Notodanthonia\i0{}, which does not have the lemma indumentum in tufts. The genus contains substantial variation, and the species from the highlands of New Guinea differ from the rest of the genus in the formation of vegetable hedgehogs, and highly reduced inflorescences.>

<\i{}Rytidosperma\i0{}, as defined here, includes the upland species from Papua New Guinea to New Zealand, and the South American species. It is close to \i{}Austrodanthonia\i0{}, from which it can be separated by the shorter callus, and to \i{}Notodanthonia\i0{}, which does not have the lemma indumentum in tufts. The genus contains substantial variation, and the species from the highlands of New Guinea differ from the rest of the genus in the formation of vegetable hedgehogs, and highly reduced inflorescences.>
<About 30 species, many native to the African tropics, with 2 species native in Australia>
<A small genus from the arid portions of northern and southern Africa. The two weedy species \i{}S. barbatus\i0{} and \i{}S. arabicus\i0{} may at times be difficult to distinguish.>
<a widespread genus of c. 110 species in tropical and warm temperate regions; 14 species in Australia, 6 nativeand 8 introduced>
<the genus is remarkably adapted to a marine habitat, mainly on intertidal mud flats, but some species extend to coastal dunes and inland freshwater swamps>

<A genus of 4 species native to eastern Asia, the Indomalayan region, the Pacific and Australia, with 3 species in Australia. These species occur on sandy coastal areas where they play an important role in dune stabilization>

<In Australia members of the \i{}S. indicus\i0{} complex have become a problem in pasture - Giants Rats Tail Grass (\i{}S. pyramidalis\i0{} and \i{}S. natalensis\i0{}), Giant Parramatta Grass (\i{}S. fertilis\i0{}), Parrammatta Grass (\i{}S. africanus\i0{}) and American Rats Tail Grass (\i{}S. jacquemontii\i0{})>
<A tropical genus of 7 species; 2 species in Australia, 1 native and 1 introduced>
<A genus of 2 species, 1 occurring in the coastal regions of Madagascar, and 1 in Indomalaya, Australia and New Guinea>

<A genus of 3 native species in the arid and semi-arid regions of inland Australia. \i{}Thyridolepis mitchelliana\i0{} is drought tolerant and an important pasture species. The spikelets are polymorphic with the lower spikelets of an inflorescence smaller with reduced vestiture. The following descriptions and key are based on spikelets from the upper part of the inflorescence>
<A South African genus, most closely related to \i{}Schismus\i0{}, but readily distinguished by the entire lemmas.>
<A monotypic genus restricted to the arid and semi-arid regions of central Australia>
<A genus of 6 species, all native to Australia, with 1 species extending to New Guinea and Malaysia>
<A genus of 4 species in Siam, Java and Australia; 3 species native in Australia>
<A genus of 7 species, 6 native in Australia and 1 in Burma>

<orthographic variants include \i{}Zoisia\i0{} J.M.Black, \i{}Fl. S. Australia\i0{} 2nd edn, 65 (1943). \i{}Zoysia matrella\i0{} (L.) Merrill and \i{}Z. tenuifolia\i0{} Willd. ex Trin. have been used as lawn grasses and sand stabilizers in northern Australia, and the latter has been collected from farmland in Victoria but apparently has not become naturalized>
<A monotypic genus endemic in central Australia>

IMMUNOELECTROPHORESIS OF GRASS POLLEN EXTRACTS (DIFFUSIBLE ANTIGENS). \par{}\par{}Each slide with rabbit antiserum in the trough, \i{}Lolium perenne\i0{} pollen extract (control) in the upper well, and comparable extracts from other genera in the lower wells, as indicated. Results are compared using raw extract (left) with those using boiled extract (right). Antigens allergenic in humans are concentrated in the heat-stable components. For experimental details and discussion of the taxonomic patterns among cross-reactions, see Watson and Knox (1976) and Watson (1983).

IMMUNOELECTROPHRESIS OF GRASS POLLEN EXTRACTS (DIFFUSIBLE ANTIGENS). \par{}\par{}Each slide with rabbit antiserum in the trough, \i{}Lolium perenne\i0{} pollen extract (control) in the upper well, and comparable extracts from other genera in the lower wells, as indicated. For experimental details and discussion of the taxonomic patterns among cross-reactios, see Watson and Knox (1976) and Watson (1983).

IMMUNOELECTROPHRESIS OF GRASS POLLEN EXTRACTS (DIFFUSIBLE ANTIGENS-HEAT-STABLE COMPONENT). \par{}\par{}Each slide with rabbit antiserum in the trough, boiled \i{}Lolium perenne\i0{} pollen extract (control) in the upper well, and comparable boiled extracts from other genera in the lower wells, as indicated. For experimental details and discussion of the taxonomic patterns among cross-reactios, see Watson and Knox (1976) and Watson (1983).

IMMUNOELECTROPHORESIS OF GRASS POLLEN EXTRACTS (DIFFUSIBLE ANTIGENS). \par{}\par{}Each slide with rabbit antiserum in the trough, \i{}Cynodon dactylon\i0{} pollen extract (control) in the upper well, and comparable extracts from other genera in the lower wells, as indicated. Results are compared using raw extract (left) with those using boiled extract (human allergens, right). For experimental details and discussion of the taxonomic patterns among cross-reactions, see Watson and Knox (1976) and Watson (1983).

IMMUNOELECTROPHORESIS OF GRASS POLLEN EXTRACTS (DIFFUSIBLE ANTIGENS). \par{}\par{}Each slide with rabbit antiserum in the trough, \i{}Lolium perenne\i0{} pollen extract (control) in the upper well, and comparable extracts from other genera in the lower wells, as indicated. For experimental details and discussion of the taxonomic patterns among cross-reactions, see Watson and Knox (1976) and Watson (1983).
